qas.question: Where was evidence of fortified settlements found?
What did some villages fortify their settlements with?

answers.text: a palisade and an outer ditch

qas.question: What tools were seen as evidence of violence among settlements?
What site in Talheim suggests violent warfare in the Neolithic era?
Where was evidence of fortified lifestyles found?

plausible_answers.text: a palisade and an outer ditch

qas.question: What did some villages fortify their lifestyles with?
What tools were seen as evidence of ditches among settlements?
What site in Talheim suggests violent warfare in the Paleolithic era?

context: There is a large body of evidence for fortified settlements at <a0_0><b4_0>Linearbandkeramik<b4_0/><a0_0/> sites along the Rhine, as at least some villages were fortified for some time with <a1_0><b5_0>a palisade and an outer ditch<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Settlements with palisades and <a2_0><b6_0>weapon-traumatized bones<b6_0/><a2_0/> have been discovered, such as at <a3_0><b7_0>the Talheim Death Pit<b7_0/><a3_0/> demonstrates "...systematic violence between groups" and warfare was probably much more common during the Neolithic than in the preceding Paleolithic period. This supplanted an earlier view of the Linear Pottery Culture as living <b8_0>a "peaceful, unfortified lifestyle<b8_0/>".
